content: as decided by my patreon supporters this month patreon choice a little my friends
welcome back to another episode of black magic crafts this is an exciting episode
for me and the reason for that is that the subject of this tutorial was decided
by my generous supporters on patreon one reality of this channel growing in
popularity is that it is no longer realistically feasible for me to even
entertain the idea of trying to make videos for all of the things that people
request in the comics but I still want to make videos that you guys really want
to see that I might not think of necessarily so as a reward to my patreon
supporters I make a monthly poll where they can vote in to decide what I'm
going to make a tutorial and at higher levels of pledges supporters can
actually submit their own topics to these polls and add on another higher
level can even actually just like straight-up decide Jeremy you're going
to make a video about this and as long as it's reasonable and on topic I will
do it if there's something you really want to see me make the only way you're
probably going to actually make that happen is if you head over to patreon
and support black magic rap which I kind of need you guys to do if possible
because that makes this channel a real thing that continues anyway that is how
you can put your question but this this episode is the patreon supporters choice
in the last poll the number one most requested topic was jungle tiles so
today I am going to show you how to make a set of overgrown jungle ruined tiles
it took me a while to get the technique that I wanted down for this tutorial
because I wanted something that really evokes a sense of jungle temple tiles
you know inspired by the Aztecs and the Lions and even the temples in Cambodia
but there was no real stone pattern I could pull from any of those that was
you know easy to maintain and wasn't just a basic you know european-style
stellar so I finally came up with something that I think looks pretty
interesting and is not that hard to do and I think you're going to like it
these tiles are perfect if you are running some kind of session in a jungle
or if you picked up tales from the awning portal and are running the hidden
shrine of commotion tamo Wiccan can watch it how do you say
it that's such a can they just called it the shrine of George and you want to be
sure that you are using the right tools materials whatever for this project you
can head over to Blackmagic craft CA and there I have my essential equipment
store and through there you can purchase all the stuff that I use on this channel
and in these builds those purchases through my affiliate store also help
support the channel find naturally so do your shopping through those links
anyways that's enough blithering and blabbering and call-to-action stuff
let's just go make a set a cool jungle ruin pile so like every other tile I
have built on this channel I'm going to start with a three inch by three inch
square of half inch thick xbs foam something I recommend doing if you've
picked up a proc song table is when you have some free time just cut up a big
batch of these blank tiles the other night I in a boat I don't know 10
minutes made about 20 or so of these just to put aside and have on hand so
that when I want to build a tile this step is already out of the way on these
tiles I want to preserve a 1 inch grid so I'm going to start by edging in the 1
inch grid on this and instead of using the knife and pen technique I'm going to
cut down on some time and do it with the hot wire so here I'm going to set my
fence at exactly 1 inch turn it on I'm going to set the temperature to
- to test this out and I'm just going to use a piece of scrap here to test how
deep this is burning at this temperature I want it to be not a huge thick line
because if it's too hot then it melts a really wide line so for me for right now
on a - is about right you may have to adjust depending on your table there's
probably some variance and I've even noticed that after doing a big batch
sometimes the temperature fluctuates and you may want to change it have it set at
a low heat standing my tile vertically and Square to the floor and I'm just
going to tap in the line just like I did on the wood tiles rotate the tile 90
degrees tap it again rotate it 90 degrees tap it again and last one room
and I'm done got a one-inch grid you can see how fast that is make a big batch of
these tiles I usually start out with a dozen when I'm making new tiles and you
can at least get this step down really quickly I also want to do a line across
the side here so that I can separate the surface stone from the side stone so
this I'm just going to eyeball it doesn't really matter
pick a you know thickness and I'm going to do the same I'm just going to tap
rotate tap rotate tap rotate and on the last one I'm going to try to make sure
that my two lines really line up call it done the one flaw with this rocks on
table is that this fence is a little bit it's not super secure so when you're
doing these you do want to keep some pressure on the fence and the other
problem is that it's fairly low so when you're doing upright cuts like this you
have to be careful not to tilt your piece that being said you can make your
own custom higher fence you can also order gerard boom from shifting lines
comm may a custom full height fence that's great
for this application but with a little bit of care you can do it with the
factory fence as I tend to do myself okay let's go over to the table and
start putting on some brick work for these tiles I wanted something that was
a little bit more intricate and interesting than just the one-inch
bricks so I decided to create a little stone pattern within the brick and it'll
just make it look a little bit more interesting to do this I'm going to use
the knife and pen method where I cut a line and then trace it back with the pen
to make a kind of v-shaped groove and I do this first with a knife and then with
a pen but if I'm doing this pattern with a knife you guys aren't going to be able
to see it on-screen very well so I am going to do it with the pen first but
keep in mind you can absolutely as long as you're confident in your layout just
go directly with the knife first to save some time essentially the way I break it
down into a repetitive task so I can do a bunch that say stay similar is that I
am going to do cross like center lines on every second pile in the same
direction you know what I'm actually going to do this I think with a marker
so you can see it a little bit better the center of every second tile in the
same direction I'm going to turn it 90 degrees and do the same thing in the
opposite direction this will just give me a bit of a starting point for a
pattern now I'm going to start breaking up these halves and I didn't make a set
kind of rule system for this I just started splitting them and trying to
keep it sort of random but sort of pattern it's a difficult thing you know
to kind of explain but the big thing is that I am intentionally not making all
of these lines perfect right angles I'm allowing them
to be slightly angled to make things I don't know a bit more you know unusual
so it doesn't look like the typical European stonework we often see in
fantasy terrain so there I've kind of now split these in random spots and then
I'm going to break these some of these down further splitting some of them in
half and my big rule with this that I seem to you know kind of give myself is
to try to not have lines on one tile directly hit lines on another kind of
offset them split them in different places and then from this point here you
can go back in and start splitting a few even further if you would like but
that's basically it just kind of don't think about it too
much just kind of go I'm going to do it with a knife but like I said this would
be actually the first way I would do it I would just do it directly freehand
with a knife and as always continue the grooves down the side of the tile as
well but I'm only going to do it up until this little line here that
separates the surface tile from the base tile and on the sides I want a stone
pattern that you know it's just a bunch of angled pieces kind of like this so it
looks like it's sitting on some heavy blocks again don't worry too much about
it don't overthink it and kind of intentionally make those lines not
straight and again cut these grooves with the exacto as well and once all
your lines are cut with the exacto you can go in and use a ballpoint pen to
bevel them do the hot wire lines as well and then start tracing around the
stonework now here you can be pretty aggressive with this and don't worry
about breaking or chipping the edge of some of these stones in fact I encourage
you to do so and actually break some of the corners and rip out some chunks or
small stones because these we want to have a worn out ruined look do not be
careful go ahead and be a little careless and aggressive with your with
your pen one thing you want to keep in mind is
that when you are doing this any little pieces that break off make sure you
fully remove them so you don't have a little floating chunks left in in the
grooves get them all out of there and of course whatever you do on the top
surface mimic on the sides and once all the line work is done being cut and
beveled you take the old tin foil ball and start giving this some texture and
one thing that helps in the look is leveling these edges a bit and you don't
even need to sand it you can just take your tinfoil ball and kind of just
aggressively run it across any sharp factory edges just to break them and
round them a bit same with these corners again you're making tiles that want to
look very well worn so you can be quite aggressive with this so aggressive that
applies across the room of course don't forget the edges I like to just stand it
on edge and roll right across with the tin foil ball once this thing is looking
well abused it is time to get it ready for
paint and as I do with all of my foam tiles and terrain I'm going to give this
thing a coat in black Mod Podge it's montage with black paint mixed in if you
have any questions or concerns about this stage of the process watch my video
about the black magic base coat because I cover this in detail so let's skip
ahead tell when my coating is dry now that the Mod Podge is dry it's time to
move on to painting and when I made my set of these tiles I wanted them to have
a little bit more of an interesting more dynamic paint job than my basic dungeon
tiles I went through a little bit more effort on the paint here and I'm going
to show you what I did now if you look at these tiles they are gray essentially
but they are different than the basic dungeon ones they have a lot more
variance in the color and while they did end up gray they ended up there in a
very kind of roundabout way that created a much more natural looking paint job
what I'm actually going to do is I'm going to paint out the tile in a very
earthy beige sort of color palette I'm going to start with a tan and then this
kind of light suede and then highlight with vanilla so rather than doing the
you know two tones of grey it's more of a two tones of beige once I have these
on they are going to have a really kind of desert stone look to them you can
actually take this paint job and apply it to terrain for a kind of like desert
environment but I am then going to do some washes on it that's going to bring
it back to grey except with a lot more interesting undertones so you can
actually use this technique in different ways and also if you want to just take
these tiles and paint them out in just a two-tone gray that's fine I just wanted
my set of these to be a little bit more dynamic looking and I want to show you
that there's many different ways to end up with grey and there's a lot of
interesting options when you're painting so anyways the first thing that I'm
going to do as paint out the entire piece in this
tan this is craft smart can it's a very kind of it's like like a gray beige has
a nice natural stone look to it and I'm going to completely paint the whole
piece and as I usually do I try to actually get in all the nooks and
crannies and then let the washes actually bring back out the black lines
once you have the whole thing covered go around to any of these big deep divots
and kind of brush out the excess paint that might be sitting in there because
you want this piece to be pretty much fully dried before moving on to the next
highlight color and if you have these pools of paint in these low spots it's
going to take a lot longer to dry so now the first layer of tan is dry so we're
going to move on to a lighter shade this is suede by craft smart and same way I
do on the basic dungeon tiles I am just going to give this a dry brush highlight
with this lighter tone and if you are having trouble with your dry brushing
check out the basics episode I did where I cover how to do that but basically
lighter tone going to go around and do a pretty full coverage highlight here get
quite a bit of coverage and you got to keep in mind that if you follow my
method here exactly and do the same dark wash on it that I'm going to do that
this is going to train change drastically with the wash so you really
want to overdo it with your highlights on on this and get it to a point where
it is way too bright especially when we move on to the next step with this here
with the with the vanilla picking up all these little raised bits
from the tinfoil texture and you can see here already you have a pretty
nice-looking sandstone type tile but like I said would be great for you know
a middle-eastern desert kind of environment if I wanted to keep it with
this kind of look I would probably just do a kind of light brown wash to get in
all the crevices rather than the black that I'm going to do you want to let
that dry for a little while and then break out your vanilla or off-white of
some kind here again I'm going to do more of this than I normally would if I
wasn't going to give this a dark wash that will drastically change it so it's
going to go still going light you want to only hit the highest points with this
but not worried about making this brighter than I would want now when this
paint is thoroughly dry we can move on to the wash stage and it's important
that this is totally dry before doing it if you're impatient break out the
hairdryer and speed up the drying process but don't do this until it is
dry so here I have a basic black wash that I cover in the black wash episode
the same exact batch that I used on my wood tiles that I've saved in this
bottle here it's a black wash with a bit of brown mixed in as well and just give
it a shake because it's been sitting for a while
and I'm going to pour a bunch into this Tupperware here enough that I can
completely submerge this tile like I said if you're going for a kind of
desert II sort of sandstone look maybe don't go with the black wash go with a
light brown wash but I want to bring this back into the grey territory and I
just want all of these pages to be kind of
undertones in the gray so take the tiles dip lift pour off excess sometimes you
want to dip again just to be sure and try to let once the excess come off and
then let that sit for a while so now my wash is pretty much dry leave it as long
as possible but I'm in a hurry here so there's still some wash in the crevices
that's wet but that's okay for demonstration purposes before moving on
to the next step I want to give you a word of caution or advice when you are
doing a set of tiles like this and it involves several stages of paint I
highly recommend that you carve and get ready as many tiles as you possibly can
before moving on to paint and trying to paint out a very large batch hopefully
your entire batch that you'll ever need in one go and the reason I say that is
because when you are doing this type of paint job there are a lot of variables
and if you paint them in separate sessions even if you're following the
same steps they're going to end up looking slightly different like I did my
set last night and today and making this one for you
guys to see and the paint job is not identical it's close and if you have a
whole bunch and you kind of mix them all up it probably won't matter but if you
really want your set to kind of blend and look consistent I recommend painting
as many at once as you can so that being said it is time to dress up this tile
with a bit of greenery to give it a kind of overgrown look like it's been sitting
in the jungle for years and all sorts of plants have sprouted from the cracks and
crevices so to do that I'm going to be using two different items to do some
kind of shrubbery I am using some woodland Phoenix course turf this
is a chunky kind of foam and form or kind of moss and you know light small
plant life I'm going to be using this woodland Phoenix buying turf and the
color on this one is green grass I will try to remember to put links to some of
this stuff on my Amazon affiliate store so that you can get the right thing but
essentially use any type of flocking you can get your hands on the coarse turf
stuff doesn't really matter you can use anything that can represent kind of
chunkier plants but for the the fine kind of mossy type plant you are going
to want the finest turf you can get your hands on and if you're making homemade
flocking out of like sawdust or pencil shavings or tea or whatever you have it
may not be fine enough for this application and you might want to
actually purchase some really fine turf it is very important at least in my mind
that when you're doing this you preserve the flatness of the tile you don't want
a bunch of bumpy things that when you stand other terrain on top or Mini's it
kind of makes more crooked and cockeyed you want to have the look of overgrown
but you want it to stay flat so first I'm going to go with the coarse turf and
I'm going to attach it into some of these big chunks see this is where these
big chunks come in handy because it will allow me to embed a chunk of this coarse
turf into the tile and give it a great look but not create a huge bump so for
this I am going to attach it with a leans tacky glue you don't need much
well might need lots of you're doing lots of tiles at once and essentially
all you want to do is grab a chunk of turf dip it in the tacky glue pick it up
and stick it right into one of these voids and the stuff dries clear so you
don't have to worry about getting it you know onto
stuff and leaving exposed go through and just wherever you got a big kind of
missing piece of stone put a chunk of turf and like I said although it might
look great if you have this big bushy plant sticking up for playability it's
really important that these stay flat so you actually want to push them down flat
so a tile like this having four or five points where there's these kind of
course turf I think is enough now I'm going to do the moss so I have in here
white just it's PVA glue in a 50/50 water mix so it's very very watery I'm
going to put some in a little container and you want this to be the consistency
of you know really thin milk and just go and dab some on in a few spots kind of
working outward from where you put some of this coarse turf and let it flow into
the cracks so that when you put your turf down it looks like plant life is
growing in the cracks so once you have some spread out like that right away
just go and shake on some fine flocking and overdo it put too much on at first
and let it sit for a second and then all you got to do is tap off the excess and
you're done and of course this extra blocking that you shook off you can pour
right back into your container so you actually use very little of it at a time
and that's why some people think that this stuff might be kind of expensive
but one of these tubs will probably last you your entire you know crafting career
and so to speak and what I like to do is if I'm using a few different colors at
once and mixing it all up and yet this blend I save that mix and put it into a
separate container for a pre-mixed blend of turf so now you just got to let this
sit and let the glue dry now one last fun bit of decoration here to really
give these that cool overgrown jungle look you need to find some plastic
decorative plants you can buy these at places like Michaels or even the dollar
store all sorts of craft stores probably even Walmart it's really easy to find
little plastic plants but the trick is you have to find ones that have
individual branches with very small leaves that's the trick look for
something that has very small tiny leaves on individual branches of the
stem and you're going to want to go and cut out a couple of these for each pile
to attach them I'm actually just going to use regular super glue and it's
important that your PVA glue that you used on this stuff here is pretty dry
because super glue and PVA don't really play well together they mix in a
interesting kind of way you don't want it happening on these tiles because of
what it can do is turn into a weird bubbly white mess and I found the
easiest way to attach these is actually just to pour out a little puddle of
super glue onto a work surface and then grab a little piece of plastic plant
here and dip the whole thing into the super glue don't worry about getting on
your tweezers and get it off after and then take it and find a place in one of
those bigger Tufts and stick it in so it looks like it's growing out from
underneath it and what you want to do is takes a little bit of patience you want
to as the super glue is setting up hold it in place so that the plastic plant is
as flat as possible onto the tile because again we don't want to be
creating bumps that will make minis kind of wobble on them so there it doesn't
take that long to be careful you don't glue your tweezers right to the fern
find another one and this is up to you how much you want to put on when I did
my set of tiles I kind of went between two to four of these per tile some with
more some with less and just hold it in place till the glue sets up it doesn't
take very long here let's do a third one you can get pretty interesting with this
depending on what plants you have available these are ones that I just
already had from another project if you can find a few different varieties that
would be ideal again the most important thing is to preserve the flatness of the
tile because playability is more important than anything else and that's
it you have a tile that looks weathered and overgrown and to complete the
project I give all of these tiles a spray of Minwax fast-drying polyurethane
I use the clear satin variety always remember to spray this stuff
outside or in a well-ventilated area and try to spray from at least about 12
inches away and give light passes you want to have a heavy coating in the end
of this stuff and a total coverage but do it in light gentle passes and you
should be fine
all right now you have all the knowledge and techniques down to make your own set
and again if you want to get any of the tools or supplies that I use in this
tutorial head over to Blackmagic craft OCA and
there you can find links to all the stuff that I recommend for you of course
if you found this video useful hit that like button drop me a comment below and
if you aren't already a subscriber just hit the button I put on new episodes
every Friday it's a lot of work to make that happen so I would love it if you
subscribed and of course I got to say it as usual if you really love this channel
and you really want to help it stay afloat the best way you can do that is
by supporting black magic crafts on patreon but a lot of cool rewards for
the people that do and it is the best way to help keep this channel growing so
until I see you guys again next week happy crafting
